A grammatical form between singular and plural,
the dual is preseved in some european languages.
In Egyptian it is written as 𓏮 𓏭 𓇌 𓇋𓇋, read as ee,ei,ii,j
In Proto-Indo-European it has forms of -h₁e -ih₁ -oyh₁
In Arabic, bahrayn is the dual form of bahr ("sea") Bach⇨Bahrain⇨Bäche Baqua Bug
The late reading of 𓏭 𓇌 𓇋𓇋 as ay is consistent with the Arabic bahrayn

There is a tendency for the loss of the dual as a productive form in later Egyptian.

Provocative reading: suffix 𓏮 as di ti or bi 𓏭 𓇌 𓇋𓇋

𓃀 Ein Bein (1 foot 1 podOn 1 podUs) on/as/us=1 eins
𓂾𓃀 Beide Beine (2 poDi/feet) di=2

N:R

A lost dual form is related to the old plural suffix
二 èr -er Haus => Häuser child=>children
二 ni -en Straße => Strassen

𒉣𒉪 nun => nir 𒁴𒁴 dim² Türme tower 𒍘𒍘 du₉ دریغ dariğ Trauer #2*dun bědování دژوان dožvân 𓁹𓁹 ⲓⲣⲓ,ⲓⲉⲣ eyer 2 Eier eye(s)
𓃀𓃀 पैर pair پیر perna Latin 󳠖 punro pa по পা pierna ⇔ 발 bal parsa 𓄙 Ferse √part πόρ pór

𒉣 nun => 𒉪 nir

𒉆𒉣 nam-nun ˢʸnamnun magnificence magnificence 𒉆𒉪 nam-nir ˢʸnamnir supremacy supremacy

All plural / dual forms -r -n -ti are present in Egyptian and confused:

𓁹 eye ⲓⲣⲓ,ⲓⲉⲣ 1. eyer erst / 2 Eier
𓁹 𓏏 𓏮 eyes ⲓⲁⲧ⳼ eyeth ido@Hausa
𓂝 𓈖 𓁹 eye Auᵍen ein 1 eyen ዐይን ʿäyn yǎn 眼 𒅆 IGI / īnu 𒌋𒈨 10100=1000(𓆼)

All plural forms have singular variants:
bir iri (1 eye)
ein eyen ዐይን ʿäyn (1 eye)
first? ⲓⲁⲧ⳼ (1. eye)
